headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Why A Strong Dollar Is Good News/Bad News; Mississippi River Treasure Search; Robot Waiter Versus Human Waiter. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: MATT EGAN, CNN REPORTER
utterances.sentences: So what does a strong US. dollar mean for consumers?

utterances.speaker: KRISTINA HOOPER, CHIEF GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: The strongest U.S. dollar can be a positive to consumers, especially because many consumers buy asignificant portion of their goods from overseas. You can argue that a strong USD is something of an inflation fighter for consumers, because they are seeing some costs coming down in terms of goods. The problem is for companies and again those companies that derive their revenue from outside the U.S.

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: So if you`re an Apple or IBM or Nike, and you sell a whole bunch of stuff overseas, demand for those goods might be going down now.

utterances.speaker: HOOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, for sure. Now, I think we can`t paint the situation with a broad brush because there are some companies that are likely to hold upbetter where there`s less sensitivity to price changes. I mean that tends to be strong brands, unique products. But, yes, in general, those big multinational companies will feel an impact.

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: And is that why the stock market has been acting concerned about the strong dollar. Is it that hit to corporate profits?

utterances.speaker: HOOPER
utterances.sentences: That`s certainly one of the concerns. I mean, let`s face it, we`ve got a lot of headwinds right now. So it`s the strong dollar and again thatis largely impacting the bigger companies, the ones with more foreign exposure. There`s certainly some companies in the S&P 500 that only derive a smaller portion of revenues from outside the U.S. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten-second triviaThe Mississippi River starts in Minnesota and ends in which U.S. state? Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas or Alabama? Flowing into the Gulf of Mexico, the Mississippi River ends in Louisiana, and that`s where we`re headed next. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: A 19th century shipwreck was revealed in the drought-stricken Mississippi River.Severe drought across the Midwest has shrunk the Mississippi River to record lows. According to archaeologists, the wreck is believed to be a trading ship built in 1896 in Indiana. It`s believed a strong storm sunk the ship near Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in 1915. The wreck was first discovered in 1992 but remained largely buried until recently.

utterances.speaker: CHIP MCGIIMSEY, ARCHAELOGIST
utterances.sentences: They did some limited investigations and could look at very small pieces, basically start at two or foot wide partsof it, trying to get understanding of how it was constructed and how old it was.

utterances.speaker: SUBTITLE
utterances.sentences: With drought conditions expected to continue, more submerged treasure could be uncovered.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Okay. For all you treasure hunters out there, now you know where to look next.Next up, let`s talk about what I`m sure is one of everyone`s favorite subjects taking tests specifically let`s talk the ACT, a standardized exam used in many college`s admissions process is considered one of the benchmarks for college readiness. Well, this month, the non-profit that gives the ACT exam released some jarring news, ACT scores for this year`s graduating high school class were the lowest they`ve been since all the way back to 1991, and this is the fifth year in a row that the average scores have been going down. Why? Well, the report noted that several factors are impacting scores like the lasting effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, classroom disruptions, cyber bullying, teacher vacancies and mental health challenges. Now, a separate education report last month pointed to declining math and reading scores for nine-year-olds in the U.S. That report cited loss of in-person classroom time as the primary driver. So going ahead and give a hoot and a holler or maybe a pat on the back for your teachers today. They might not always show it, but they love you. (MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: All right. Have you noticed that robots are starting to pop up more and more. When I was in Beijing covering the Olympics earlier this year,the media`s cafeteria was almost entirely robotic. Our food was even delivered by a series of conveyor belts and robotic claws that dropped down from the ceiling. Well, for today`s out of we`re headed to Brooklyn, New York, where a robotic cat is delivering dumplings at a restaurant and is even challenging the human waiters who are kitten nervous, for real love. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CHRIS AURIGEMMA, BROOKLYN RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I have not seen this type of waiter before.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON GILLY, HIGH SCHOOL TEACHER
utterances.sentences: I traveled from Staten Island specifically to come here for the dumplings and to see the cute robot.

utterances.speaker: ROBOCAT BELLA
utterances.sentences: Keep going.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: At a Brooklyn restaurant, Dimmer and Summer, a cat robot delivers food, brings out takeout orders and helps collect dirty plates,alongside human waiters. KENNEY MEI, OWNER, DIMMER & SUMMER:  I actually have a pet review yesterday in pogo (ph), a customer it was assigned to sit upstairs and they cannot get a reach of the robot, and she`s not very happy about it.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Robocat Bella has been such a big hit that the owner is planning a new restaurant with no human waiters at all.

utterances.speaker: MEI
utterances.sentences: The robot never refuse your call and it will continue working until the store closed. We only required to be charged for five hours a day.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: So can robots really replace human waiters in restaurants? We put both to the test to find out.(MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: LEO TEN, GENERAL MANAGER AND WAITER
utterances.sentences: Hello, how are you? Good morning.

utterances.speaker: AURIGEMMA
utterances.sentences: How you doing?

utterances.speaker: TEN
utterances.sentences: Doing good.When it comes to taking order, humans always the best. What can I get you today? We have conversation. You guys -- But the robot she just humming every time. The robot couldn`t take orders because that is not one of the function that the robot has. (MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: TEN
utterances.sentences: I can deliver food faster than the robot, but I don`t know if the robot can carry more plays than me. I think I feel pretty good with that.

utterances.speaker: ROBOCAT BELLA
utterances.sentences: I am the best waiter here.

utterances.speaker: AURIGEMMA
utterances.sentences: Could I have the check please?

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: That`s right, this robot cat cannot respond to requests about the check, but can deliver it once the waiter programs it to get to aspecific table.

utterances.speaker: AURIGEMMA
utterances.sentences: Can we just have the check please?

utterances.speaker: TEN
utterances.sentences: Sure. Here we go.

utterances.speaker: AURIGEMMA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: TEN
utterances.sentences: I don`t think the robot can complete with me right now, but 10 years, 20 years later, I think the robots replace us no problem.

utterances.speaker: AURIGEMMA
utterances.sentences: I prefer the human waiter for the recommendations for what to eat.

utterances.speaker: GILLY
utterances.sentences: I don`t think I would say one is better than the other it was just the experience of seeing the robot waiter was a lot more exciting than thehuman waiters. Sorry, no offense, but if I had to pick anything about my experience here, 100 percent the dumplings. (END VIDEOTAPE)
